posts.name: Noah
posts.cooked: I'm facing significant challenges right now. Over the past few days, I discovered that keyboards can be used to program robots. Impressed, I decided to try it. I began by writing a piece of code utilizing a library that sends keyboard inputs to a dashboard interface. Unfortunately, the code failed when integrated with Rio. Since then, I've been unsure of the next steps. Can anyone offer guidance on alternative methods? I also came across software that simulates a joystick, but other programmers cautioned against its use in real-world scenarios. If anyone has similar experience, kindly share your insights.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: In the last few days I‚Äôve seen that it‚Äôs possible to use keyboards to pilot robots Can you link in some of the topics / posts you were looking at?

posts.name: Noah
posts.cooked: I see this topic but I don‚Äôt know Python and I don‚Äôt know very well how to use these external codes the little I know about programming is only for robots within VS Code I don‚Äôt understand much about other concepts.So I looked for Java adaptations with a bit of chatGPT and VS Code tutorials on YouTube

link_counts.title: Keyboard and Mouse as a controller... (again)

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked: More detail here is needed. However, one issue I am aware of is pygame window needs to be in focus. This means the pygame window must be on top. This is especially important after you click enable on the DS Driver Station as window focus will go to the DS Driver Station. You need to click on the pygame window to have your input captured. Otherwise, nothing will work. Additionally, on code inst.setServer('127.0.0.1') in the Python script you need to change that to your roboRIO IP address. It would also be helpful if you have your Java code available.

posts.name: Noah
posts.cooked: In reality, I didn't understand how to use Pygame, and the only thing I developed was a class within my code in VS Code that sent data to the network table whenever a key was pressed. I don't have the complete code in Git, but I'll share at least the part of the class.

posts.name: Noah
Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked: What your code is trying to do here is capture local keystroke. Unfortunately, roboRIO doesn‚Äôt have a keyboard attached, so this won‚Äôt work. My pygame speaks via NetworkTables. Keyboard inputs are treated as buttons, and mouse movements are treated as analogue inputs. You need to subscribe to these values and have your actuators respond accordingly.

link_counts.title: What is NetworkTables ‚Äî FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.cooked: yup i can confirm that this is correct. you can also set up a trigger to bind commands to observing things in networktables. our code, which supports keyboard controls, is available at github - aesatchien/frc2429_2025: python code for frc 2429's 2025 robot(s). however, it is probably not as easy to understand as @nathanzhou's approach. please note that polling all this functionality consumes some loop time. despite this, it saved us a few instances at tidal when the controller went offline.

link_counts.title: GitHub - aesatchien/FRC2429_2025: Python code for FRC 2429's 2025 robot(s)

posts.name: Ezra
posts.cooked: This is our code for it: RobotCode2025/src/main/python/keyboard_to_nt.py at main ¬∑ Programming-TRIGON/RobotCode2025 ¬∑ GitHub. This code just runs in the background on the computer and publishes all keys to the nt. We use it with this https://github.com/Programming-TRIGON/TRIGONLib/blob/main/src/main/java/org/trigoni/hardware/misc/KeyboardController.java.

The easiest way we‚Äôve done it is to use a program called KeyboardSplitter, which converts a keyboard into an Xbox controller detected by the Driver Station. In years past, we‚Äôve used a mechanical numpad as an operator controller by binding the buttons on it to Xbox buttons.

link_counts.title: GitHub - djlastnight/KeyboardSplitterXbox: Creates up to 4 virtual xbox 360 controllers and feeds them via one or more keyboards.

posts.cooked: Instead of using NetworkTables, we wrote a Python script that uses the vjoy library to create a virtual controller, which the robot can then see as raw HID buttons. The window does not need to be focused. This was very robust and performed well at 4 different competitions. Earlier versions of this file used the vgamepad library to emulate an Xbox 360 controller but ran out of buttons.

posts.name: Karl Olson
posts.cooked: We used vgamepad along with a Stream Deck Python API to create an operator button board. This setup worked very well. By utilizing the axes as bit fields, we were able to significantly increase the number of usable buttons: 8 additional buttons per trigger and 16 per joystick axis, resulting in a total of 80 extra buttons.

link_counts.title: GitHub - yannbouteiller/vgamepad: Virtual XBox360 and DualShock4 gamepads in python
